diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by acute and chronic inflammation of various tissues of the body.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A type of arthritis that causes joint inflammation and stiffness for more than six weeks in a child aged 16 or younger. It can also cause fevers and rash.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In addition to joint problems, it can also present with fever and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory type of arthritis that occurs in some patients with psoriasis. This condition can affect the skin, joints, and areas where tissues attach to bone.

diagnoses.name: Tuberous Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes non-cancerous (benign) tumors to develop in many parts of the body. Seizures are a common symptom due to the development of brain tumors.

diagnoses.name: Leptospirosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial disease that affects humans and animals. It can lead to kidney damage, meningitis, liver failure, respiratory distress, and even death.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An illness that causes inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body. It mainly affects children. The symptoms can be severe for children but are often mild for adults.

diagnoses.name: Scrub Typhus
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by a bacteria called Orientia tsutsugamushi. Symptoms include fever, rash, and potential complications such as pneumonitis or encephalitis.

diagnoses.name: Hypervitaminosis A
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from excessive consumption of Vitamin A. Symptoms can include vision problems, skin changes, and bone pain.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Epilepsy (secondary to CNS lupus or vasculitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by systemic inflammation affecting multiple organs including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and others. This condition may present with various combinations of the listed symptoms due to its systemic nature.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Extra-Articular Manifestations
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease primarily affecting the joints but can also cause systemic issues including leukopenia, pericardial effusion, and skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that may present with features of several connective tissue diseases, including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, often with high levels of ribonucleoprotein antibodies.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, sometimes associated with other autoimmune conditions.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. The erythematous-violaceous rash often appears on the face, knuckles, neck, shoulders, upper chest, and back.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth but can also cause systemic complications, including arthropathy and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease (UCTD)
diagnoses.description: A disease that presents with signs and symptoms of connective tissue diseases but does not fulfill the criteria for a specific disease. Patients may experience a variety of symptoms including those listed.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that cause skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. Some patients may present with pericardial effusion, arthropathy, and leukopenia among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by fever, rash, and joint pain. Arthralgia, leukopenia, and pericardial effusion can be present among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by antiphospholipid antibodies that can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including but not limited to thrombosis, leukopenia, and heart involvement.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (with concurrent autoimmune or rheumatologic disease)
Lyme Disease (with neurological and rheumatological manifestations)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the nervous system (seizures, psychosis), hematologic (autoimmune hemolysis), cardiac (pericardial effusion), and musculoskeletal systems (arthropathy).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis with Extra-articular Features
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting joints, it can have systemic manifestations including hematologic (autoimmune hemolysis), and rarely, neurological (seizures, psychosis) and cardiac (pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the exocrine glands but can have systemic manifestations including neurologic (seizures), hematologic (autoimmune hemolysis), and possibly arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Is known to cause blood clotting issues that can lead to seizures, and it can be associated with autoimmune hemolysis and other autoimmune diseases that could explain the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A disorder featuring a combination of symptoms of SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including potential for neurological symptoms (seizures, psychosis), hematological issues (autoimmune hemolysis), arthropathy, and cardiac involvement (pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Though rare, can present with neurological involvement (seizures, psychosis), and vascular complications which can indirectly lead to symptoms like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Primary CNS Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Could primarily cause neurological symptoms (seizures, psychosis) and indirectly other symptoms due to vascular involvement throughout the body.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder that can lead to autoimmune hemolysis as well as potential for other autoimmune manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can present with a pericardial effusion, autoimmune hemolysis, seizures (due to CNS involvement), and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Might have less association with seizures and psychosis but can involve autoimmune hemolysis, cardiac (pericardial effusion), and arthropathy.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (with systemic infection contributing to fever and leukopenia)
Schizophrenia (secondary to systemic disease, rare manifestation)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Epstein-Barr virus, COVID-19)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, heart, brain, and joints, causing inflammation and tissue damage in the affected parts.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic manifestations including pericardial effusion and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with features of three other connective tissue diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; can present with leukopenia, synovitis, and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the mouth and eyes. Systemic features can include nephritis and neurological manifestations like seizures.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation, which can lead to various symptoms including nephritis and neurological symptoms like seizures.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidneys caused by systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), a type of autoimmune disease.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Cardiac, renal, and neurological involvement can occur.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which can lead to numerous symptoms including those affecting the brain (neuro-Behcet’s), which may manifest as seizures.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that increases the risk of blood clots. Can cause kidney damage, neurological symptoms including seizures, and cardiac involvement.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: Infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves, which can spread infection through the bloodstream, potentially leading to kidney damage, neurological complications including seizures, and heart complications like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with secondary autoimmune complications
Vasculitis with CNS and pulmonary manifestations
Enteric Fever (Salmonella Typhi or Paratyphi Infection)
Viral infections such as Dengue fever, COVID-19, or Ebola
Bacterial infections like sepsis or bacterial endocarditis
Other hematologic conditions like aplastic anemia
Tick-borne diseases such as Ehrlichiosis or Anaplasmosis
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Parvovirus)
Viral infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Oral Cavity

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by acute and chronic inflammation of various tissues of the body.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, specifically in the disease-fighting white blood cells called lymphocytes. It can cause lymphadenopathy and chest pain among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Castleman Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder involving an overgrowth of cells in the body's lymph nodes. It can cause symptoms similar to lymphoma including lymphadenopathy and chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous signs and symptoms that may initially seem unrelated, including mouth sores, eye inflammation, skin rashes and lesions, and genital sores.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs, but can also affect lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and interferes with your body's ability to fight the organisms that cause disease. AIDS is the late stage of HIV infection.

diagnoses.name: Cat Scratch Disease
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae, usually following a scratch or bite from a cat. It can cause lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause the lymph nodes to enlarge.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that causes changes in the blood vessel walls, including thickening, weakening, narrowing, and scarring. It can lead to a variety of symptoms including chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue, which can lead to a variety of symptoms including skin abnormalities and neurological issues.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. MS can cause a wide range of symptoms, including muscle weakness, trouble with coordination and balance, sensations such as numbness, prickling, or pins and needles, and thinking and memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body. Symptoms may include mouth sores, eye inflammation, skin rashes and lesions, and genital sores.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease caused when the immune system attacks its own tissues. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever. It can also affect the nervous system and brain.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It is often associated with other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Fibromyalgia can sometimes present with symptoms similar to those of arthritis or lupus.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipelining, potentially leading to dysphagia among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can lead to a wide variety of symptoms, including neurological and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Nonepileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Seizure-like episodes that are thought to have a psychological origin rather than a neurological one. PNES are a manifestation of psychological distress.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Asthma (with normal pulmonary function tests during symptom-free periods)
Chronic back pain - Possible causes include musculoskeletal disorders, spinal stenosis, or chronic strain.
Lymphadenopathy - This symptom can indicate infections (such as TB, mononucleosis), autoimmune diseases, or malignancies like lymphoma or leukemia.
Leukoplakia - Often related to chronic irritation, such as smoking or alcohol use, but can also be a precancerous condition, particularly in the oral cavity.
Tinnitus - Usually related to auditory system disturbances but can also be associated with conditions like Meniere's disease, chronic otitis media, or as a side effect of certain medications.
Congestion - Can be a symptom of chronic rhinosinusitis, allergies, or nasal polyps.
HIV/AIDS - Given the combination of lymphadenopathy, leukoplakia, and chronic illnesses, this could be a consideration.
Lupus - Autoimmune diseases like lupus can present with a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy and chronic pain.
Sjögren's Syndrome - Another autoimmune disease that can present with chronic pain and has been associated with leukoplakia.
Sarcoidosis - This disease can cause lymphadenopathy, chronic pain, and skin manifestations.
Chronic Fatigue Syndrome - Though less specific, it could be considered given chronic pain and the generalised symptoms like tinnitus and congestion.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These extra cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications like aneurysms and thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause narrowing, weakening, narrowing, or scarring. This can lead to reduced blood flow that might manifest as presyncope and aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body produces too many platelets, leading to thrombosis (clots within blood vessels) which can manifest as dyspnea and aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue that results in excessive production of adrenaline. The symptoms can include high blood pressure, decreased appetite, and presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the heart is unable to pump sufficiently to maintain blood flow to meet the body’s needs. It can manifest with dyspnea even when pulmonary function tests are normal due to cardiac reasons rather than pulmonary.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can lead to thrombocytosis and decreased appetite among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyperviscosity Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood becomes thick, which can result from conditions like polycythemia. Symptoms can include decreased appetite, dyspnea, and neurological symptoms such as presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the body doesn't have enough iron to produce hemoglobin for red blood cells, leading to thrombocytosis in some cases. Symptoms can include dyspnea and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart. In its early stages, it might cause dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels (most often the temporal arteries) that can lead to significant complications like aneurysms if left untreated.

diagnoses: Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy) - can cause easy bruising
Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) - can manifest as obsessive-compulsive behavior
Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome - associated with easy bruising
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) - can cause oral pain
Dental issues (e.g., cavities, gum disease) - leading to oral pain
Zinc deficiency - can lead to dysosmia
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Lung

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. The excess iron is stored in various organs, particularly the liver. Hyperferritinemia is a common finding in hemochromatosis.

diagnoses.name: Iron Overload
diagnoses.description: A condition arising from the accumulation of too much iron in the body, often due to chronic blood transfusions or excessive dietary iron. Symptoms may include liver disease, diabetes mellitus, and hyperpigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can lead to fever, rash, and joint pain. Elevated ferritin levels are often seen. Other symptoms may include sore throat and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the immune system. Patients are prone to infections and may exhibit symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions. Hyperferritinemia can also occur due to frequent infections and inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks glands that produce saliva and tears. It can cause dry mouth and dry eyes (xerosis), along with fatigue and joint pain. Tinnitus might be present due to associated neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can include skin rash, fatigue, fever, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that results in an increased level of circulating red blood cells. Symptoms can include headaches, dizziness, tinnitus, and itching after bathing (aquagenic pruritus).

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Reactions can range from mild hypersensitivity to severe anaphylaxis. Symptoms can include rash, hives, itching, and potentially xerosis as a secondary effect to skin barrier disruption.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism can lead to symptoms like hyperactivity (in hyperthyroidism) or hypersensitivity reactions. Imbalances in thyroid hormones can also indirectly affect skin moisture, leading to xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including but not limited to sensory disturbances (which may explain tinnitus), fatigue, hyperactivity (in terms of spasticity or muscle spasms), and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a significant increase in heart rate upon standing, often accompanied by symptoms like lightheadedness, fainting, and rapid heartbeat.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It's commonly associated with POTS and can lead to a variety of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells, potentially leading to a wide range of symptoms, including allergy-like symptoms, dysautonomia, and sometimes basophilia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by severe fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks your own body. Conditions like lupus or Sjögren’s syndrome might present with a wide array of symptoms similar to those described.

diagnoses.name: Small Fiber Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting small fiber nerves, leading to symptoms like pain, burning, and autonomic dysfunction, which can include symptoms of POTS.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, leading to demyelination, which can present with a wide range of symptoms, including those mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including neurological and cardiac symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.description: A condition of the bladder causing pain and pressure in the bladder area, often accompanied by urinary frequency and urgency. It can coexist with other systemic conditions or occur as a primary condition.

diagnoses: Anxiety disorder due to a general medical condition
Secondary Immunodeficiency due to Medication or Illness

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity reactions
diagnoses.description: An exaggerated response by the immune system to a drug or other substance.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the glands that produce saliva and tears, leading to dry mouth and eyes.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: The growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious illness usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, characterized by swollen lymph nodes, fever, sore throat, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections.

diagnoses.name: Acute HIV infection
diagnoses.description: The initial period following the contraction of HIV, characterized by flu-like symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: An area of swelling of the lower layer of skin and tissue just under the skin or mucous membranes. The swelling may occur in the face, tongue, larynx, abdomen, or arms and legs. Often it is associated with hives, which are swelling within the upper skin.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection
diagnoses.description: HPV infection can cause warts and has been associated with various cancers. While it doesn't directly cause lymphadenopathy or lymphadenitis, immune response to the infection may lead to these conditions.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) can manifest with lymphadenopathy as the immune system is compromised. Chronic pain and other opportunistic infections like HPV leading to warts can be related complications.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.description: TB is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body. It can cause lymphadenitis and systemic symptoms such as fever.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Lymphoma, including Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands, causing lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that can cause chronic pain, including back pain, and may lead to lymphadenopathy due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause lymphadenopathy. Tertiary syphilis can lead to chronic pain and various other symptoms throughout the body.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as mono, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it often presents with fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph glands, including lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Cat Scratch Disease
diagnoses.description: Caused by Bartonella henselae, this infection can result in lymphadenopathy. It's often contracted from a cat scratch or bite.

diagnoses.name: Spinal Infections
diagnoses.description: Infections of the spine, including bacterial or tuberculous spondylitis, can cause chronic back pain and systemic symptoms such as fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Sjögren's syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems in the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including leukopenia (reduced white blood cell count), neuropathies, and potentially epistaxis due to vasculitis. Neuropsychiatric SLE can lead to depression.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.rationale: ITP can lead to epistaxis due to low platelet counts and also might be associated with leukopenia. Mood changes or depression can be associated with the disease or its treatment.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause sensory neuropathies due to the degeneration of the myelin sheath, depression due to its role in neurotransmitter synthesis, and leukopenia. Although less directly, it could contribute to dysmenorrhea through its impact on overall health.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.rationale: MS can cause sensory neuropathies due to nerve damage from the autoimmune attack on myelin. Depression is common in MS patients. While MS does not directly cause leukopenia, epistaxis, or dysmenorrhea, the associated stress and treatments could contribute to these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behcet's Disease is a chronic condition that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. It can lead to symptoms including epistaxis and neuropathies. Leukopenia and depression could be related to the disease or its treatments.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic Hepatitis C infection can cause leukopenia and has been associated with sensory neuropathies. Depression is a common symptom among hepatitis C patients. It might indirectly affect menstrual cycles, potentially worsening dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.rationale: While PCOS is primarily known to affect menstrual cycles and cause dysmenorrhea, it is also associated with depression. The connection with leukopenia, sensory neuropathies, and epistaxis is less direct but may occur due to associated metabolic or hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: Iron deficiency anemia can cause leukopenia and has been associated with symptoms like dysmenorrhea. It can also contribute to depression. There's not a direct association with sensory neuropathies or epistaxis, but overall health decline might contribute to these conditions.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV/AIDS can cause leukopenia as the virus attacks the immune system. Sensory neuropathies are also a common complication. Patients with HIV/AIDS can experience depression due to the psychological impact of the disease. Epistaxis and dysmenorrhea can occur but are less directly associated.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.rationale: Fibromyalgia is associated with central pain sensitization which may resemble sensory neuropathies. It's also closely linked with depression. There is not a direct link to leukopenia, epistaxis, or dysmenorrhea, but the overall syndrome could impact or exacerbate these symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that can affect the skin and mucous membranes, possibly leading to leukoplakia, vulvodynia, and mood changes due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder affecting the immune system, potentially leading to frequent infections such as lymphadenitis, and may present with skin manifestations that could contribute to leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which might explain dyspnea, vulvodynia, and leukoplakia due to mucous membrane involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily attacks the glands that produce tears and saliva, possibly explaining leukoplakia and leading to systemic symptoms affecting mood and causing dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome can lead to various symptoms, including lymphadenitis, leukoplakia due to immune suppression, mood changes, and potentially affect pulmonary function.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin (leukoplakia), respiratory system (dyspnea), and nervous system (mood lability), alongside causing lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form as nodules in multiple organs, potentially causing pulmonary symptoms, lymphadenitis, and skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted through tick bites. It can lead to various symptoms, including mood lability, possibly dyspnea, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory bowel disease that can cause inflammation in different parts of the digestive tract, potentially leading to symptoms like vulvodynia and systemic issues affecting mood and lymphatic system.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Dyspnea
diagnoses.description: Also known as hyperventilation syndrome, this condition involves rapid or deep breathing that can occur due to anxiety or mood disorders, potentially linking mood lability to dyspnea symptoms.

diagnoses: Electrolyte Imbalance (including Hyponatremia, Hypernatremia, Hypokalemia, Hyperkalemia)
Blepharospasm as part of a neurodegenerative disorder
Urinary Tract Infection leading to sepsis
Stroke leading to central nervous system dysfunction
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Allergic reaction to food or medication
Hormonal imbalances such as menopause or pheochromocytoma
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to symptoms such as hives, angioedema (swelling), rhinorrhea (runny nose), and potentially syncope (fainting) due to a drop in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other parts of the body, which can lead to symptoms such as hives, angioedema, syncope, and incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing recurring episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), hives, and potentially life-threatening laryngeal edema. Abdominal attacks may also cause transient incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a carcinoid tumor secretes certain chemicals into your bloodstream, causing symptoms like flushing of the skin, hives, rhinorrhea, and in rare cases, syncope.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting (syncope) that can occur in response to a trigger, such as emotional distress or prolonged standing. It may be associated with temporary incontinence due to loss of muscle control during fainting.

diagnoses.name: Neurocardiogenic Syncope
diagnoses.description: A subset of vasovagal syncope, where the trigger for the syncope is often a result of a malfunction in the part of the nervous system that regulates heart rate and blood pressure. Associated symptoms could include rhinorrhea or angioedema if triggered by allergens.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects circulation (blood flow) and can cause syncope, incontinence, and, less frequently, hives or angioedema as part of an allergic response or associated with autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Shy-Drager Syndrome (Multiple System Atrophy)
diagnoses.description: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by a combination of symptoms, including autonomic dysfunction (which could lead to incontinence and syncope), and in some cases, allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can present a wide range of symptoms, including hives, angioedema, and in rare cases, syncope due to cardiovascular involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of blood disorders characterized by an overproduction of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell. Patients may present with hives, angioedema, and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Allergic reaction to food or medication
Autoimmune disorders (such as systemic lupus erythematosus)
Functional gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., irritable bowel syndrome)
Toxic Effects (from substances such as alcohol or drugs)
Multiple Sclerosis (considering cranial neuropathy and psychosis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Lupus Erythematosus with Secondary Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia + Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not directly related to underlying disease)
